body.para: TypeParametersThis is supported for methods with generic type arguments. This something like <T> for a method with one type parameter named T. Usually one of the parameters in the parameter list is then also of type T.

<idParam>A function parameter variable. A variable specified in this manner is automatically declared local. These variables, also called formal parameters, are used to receive arguments that you pass when you call the function.

AS | REF <idType>Specifies the data type of the parameter variable (called strong typing). AS indicates that the parameter must be passed by value, and REF indicates that it must be passed by reference with the @ operator.
The valid values for <idType> and the initial values associated with each are listed in the table below:

Note: NULL_ARRAY is the initial value for an array declared using, for example, LOCAL <idArray> AS ARRAY. If you specify array dimensions as part of the declaration you are, in effect, making an assignment to the array and, therefore, NULL_ARRAY will not apply.
See the "Variables, Constants, and Declarations" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for a complete discussion of data types and the advantages of strong typing.

AS <idType>Specifies the data type of the function return value. Note that in addition to all of the <idType> values listed in the table above, functions can be declared with AS VOID to indicate that the function has no return value.
See the "Variables, Constants, and Declarations" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for a complete discussion of data types and the advantages of strong typing.

AS <idType>Specifies the data type of the method return value. Note that in addition to all of the <idType> values listed in the table above, functions can be declared with AS VOID to indicate that the function has no return value.
See the "Variables, Constants, and Declarations" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for a complete discussion of data types and the advantages of strong typing.

Note If you declare the return type of a method you must also strong type its parameters, specify the calling convention and you need to declare the method in the CLASS declaration. See section about strong typed methods below.
TypeParameterConstraintsHere you can specify constraints for the Type parameters, such as WHERE T IS SomeName or WHERE T IS New
EXPORT LOCALThis clause is allowed by X# but ignored.
